properties.Comments: This is a .large sprawling tree, with dark leaves that turn a wonderful purple in the autumn. It is rare, and the two best are by the Wills Tower and in the Zoo, ref No148

properties.Place: Knoll Hill, Bishops Knoll Wood, Bramble Lane Stoke Bishop
properties.Comments: It is very rare in Bristol, and the best is at the Bishops Knoll Wood, with a girth of 295cm, ref No108

properties.Scientific_Name: Populus alba x tremula = P. x canescens
properties.Comments: Distinguished by the black diamond shaped pits on its trunk. The largest with a girth of 230cm, ref No156
girth 520cm age 150. This is the tree growing in splendour close to the House. It is 33m high, but with a smaller girth than the one by the pond, ref No44
A rare tree with large leaves with seven leaflets on each, which has just been planted, ref No77

properties.Place: Blaise House, within the children?s playground
properties.Comments: Sometimes called Nettle Tree, this is a rare tree, planted in what was a mini arboretum at Blaise House, now within the children?s playground, ref No99
Two very fine trees in Clifton have collapsed in the past two years, and the largest now has a girth of 300cm, ref No169
The largest is in Eastville Park with girth of 240cm. Fast growing and almost evergreen, recently planted in parks and as a street tree, prominent on Park Row, ref No53
This species is common in the north west of the UK, and is locally rare, this tree has a girth of 400cm, ref No144

properties.Place: Clifton Downs, Growing out of a small fissure in the vertical cliff at the bottom of the Gully
properties.Comments: It is a natural Bonsai, and could be any age, ref No196

properties.Place: The entrance to Eastwood Farm Park
properties.Comments: There is an avenue of them at Oldbury Court, and at  Eastwood Farm Park. There is a young tree on Woodland road with a girth of just 170cm, but which is nearly 30m high, ref No88

properties.Place: Blaise, close to the main house
properties.Comments: girth 695cm, age 250. Cedars grow exceptionally fast and this tree is probably not more than 250 years old, but it is the finest in Bristol, occupying a very prominent position, ref No9

properties.Place: Blaise, in the meadows off Henbury Lane
properties.Comments: This tree in the Blaise meadows and has five trunks, each with a girth of 280cm, and the whole is 700cm in circumference, ref No199

properties.Place: Oldbury Court, near the main path down to the Frome
properties.Comments: This is the finest and commonest of the firs but is rare in Bristol. The best planted c 1955, is now the tallest tree in the estate, with a girth of 280cm, ref No97

properties.Place: Oldbury court, in the woods on the northern edge of the park, set above the almost vertical drop to the River Frome below
properties.Comments: Girth 570cm, age 380, ref No27
A handsome common conifer with a distinctive egg shaped fruit, it often has branches coming horizontally from the base of its trunk. Girth of 300cm, ref No174

A Victorian cemetery favourite, achieved by grafting as high as possible, as the branches grow straight downwards. There are a number in Greville Smythe Park, the largest with a girth of 210cm, ref No60

properties.Place: Clifton, front garden in Cecil Road Clifton, close to the zoo
properties.Comments: It is not common, ref No155

properties.Place: Victory Park, Brislington, approximate grid reference only used
properties.Comments: Girth of 425cm in Victory Park, ref No56
A very rare tree from Korea. It is evergreen, and not especially impressive, and is in St Andrews Churchyard in Clifton. It is multi trunked, and related to Laurel, ref No135
A slow growing small native species, common in hedges, and hence often multi-trunked, and probably older than they look. The largest girth was measured at 370cm, ref No126
This is a small evergreen Oak planted in Castle Park,  a girth of 150 cm, ref No141

This was an original planting in 1840, and before it was felled had a girth of 570cm. The massive stump was brilliantly sculpted in the form of an elephant with a series of animals on its back, diminishing in size upwards, ref No183

properties.Place: Stoke Park, northern edge of the main path through the wood
properties.Comments: Girth of 500cm. Is probably 300 years old. Likely to have been planted for aesthetic reasons, for the woods were managed for wood and timber, ref No32

properties.Place: Ashton Park, beside the main drive
properties.Sex__Stage: hollow veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: girth 820cm, age 700 years. A magnificent veteran, reduced to a substantial stump, but still vigorous. This is just one of over a hundred ancient pollard oaks in the park, the largest group in the country outside Windsor Great Park, ref No1
There are three Cedars all the same size and age, though one unfortunately is dying. There are probably more Lebanon Cedars in Britain than in the state of Lebanon, ref No17
A delightful small multi-trunk evergreen tree from South America. The Zoo has number of them, ref No63
An uncommon tree that flowers in August, a girth of 200cm, ref No165

properties.Sex__Stage: hollow veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: There is an avenue of them at Oldbury Court, and at Eastwood Farm Park. There is a young tree on Woodland road with a girth of just 170cm, but which is nearly 30m high, ref No88
Always grafted this is similar to the Silver Lime, but with a weeping form, this one dates back to 1840 and has a girth of 350cm. It dominates the local landscape, ref No120
Girth 540cm, age 200. The tree has a very decided lean. It is one of the parents of the London Plane, but is now very rarely planted, though it grows just as fast, ref No37
There are three Cedars all the same size and age, though one unfortunately is dying. There are probably more Lebanon Cedars in Britain than in the state of Lebanon, ref No15
Commonly planted in avenues, of which the best known is the Promenade in Clifton, the oldest trees in which are 100 years old. 480cm girth on the Downs, ref No65
A native small tree, and a number of varieties and species are often planted in gardens and car parks, but rarely in parks. Present in Canford Cemetery and Cumberland Basin, ref No163

girth 625cm, age 450. Oldest and largest in Bristol, vigorous multi-trunk maiden, isolated20 feet above the road that had been driven past it. From a distance it looks like an ordinary tree, but its base is well below the level of York Place, ref No13

This species is widely planted for its delicious fruit, but is very often found growing horizontally, as it is in Victoria Square. The largest is in the gardens of the Royal Fort with a girth of 230cm, ref No73

This is very frequently planted in gardens, and has proved to be hardy. Very fast growing, but only planted recently in Victoria Park, a fine one is in front garden of Pembroke Road in Clifton, ref No98

properties.Scientific_Name: Salix alba x babylonica = S. x sepulcralis
properties.Comments: A familiar form that grows very rapidly. The largest is in Canford Cemetery with a girth of 250cm, ref No177
Spruces are uncommon in Bristol. This species has branches hung with pendulous branchlets, ref No69
Has very unusual attractive leaves and small black fruit in papery bladders. This tree has a girth of 110cm, ref No159
Girth 530cm, age 300. This is the largest of a number of the oaks. But demand for timber fell sharply in the 19th century so that a large number of veteran trees remain, ref No39
This is a rare tree closely related to the Hornbeam, with fruit that look like a bunch of ripe hops. There are a group of three healthy young trees, ref No102

properties.Place: City Docks, grows in the vertical wall just east of Bristol Bridge
properties.Comments: Every so often it is heavily reduced so that it does not create problems for the river traffic, ref No188

properties.Place: Knoll Hill, Bishops Knoll Wood, Bramble Lane, Stoke Bishop
properties.Comments: It will coppice and this can be seen in action on Richmond Hill. The largest is in the Bishops Knoll Wood with a girth of 400cm, but it is 150 years old at most, ref No160
This is a natural variant with cut leaves. The finest is in Victoria Square, Clifton, with a girth of 480cm. It dates back to the original planting c 1860, ref No67

properties.Place: Downs, at the bottom of Ladies Mile
properties.Comments: One large tree, a Huntingdon Elm, survives on the Downs with a girth of 250cm, ref No93

The only specimens are two in the Zoo. They grow in columnar form and have a girth of 300cm implying that they are over a century old. One hangs over the wall of College Road, the other is close by, ref No104
A rare small native tree, with a girth of 150cm, ref No164

girth 540cm, age 160. This is the largest Copper Beech in Bristol. It grows in the private front garden of the mansion, dominating its surroundings, and shows what a magnificent tree the Beech can be when grown free from competition, ref No35

properties.Scientific_Name: Salix euxina x alba = S. x fragilis
properties.Place: Sparke Evans park, on the bank of the Avon, Sparke Evans Park
properties.Comments: Distinguished by the fact that branchlets snap off, it is a very common native tree, but rare in parks. Two very large ones, ref No175
They sometimes grow with multiple trunks from close to the ground. A girth of 260cm. It is a weirdly twisted and contorted specimen, ref No117
This is very frequently planted in gardens, and has proved to be hardy. Very fast growing, but only planted recently in Victoria Park, ref No98
Named for its dramatic white flowers in spring, ref No61

properties.Place: Brislington Victory Park, has its feet in the stream, on the northern edge of the park
properties.Comments: 580 cm in girth and perhaps 380 years old. Has its feet in the stream, on the northern edge of the park, which may account for its vigour, ref No25
The finest is on the mound created as a feature by Humphrey Repton, the first landscape designer. The Mound has about ten Sycamores on it, the largest with a 400cm girth, ref No168

A towering pine in the Kings Weston estate has a girth of 320cm, but most unusually splits into two main trunks, both growing vertically at about 20 metres up. It may have suffered a lightning strike, ref No197

properties.Place: Henbury, in fields and hedges belonging to the Riding for the Disabled Association
Eastville Park, eastern end of lake
properties.Comments: a huge pollard girth 520cm. This giant must have existed before the park was created and should be 300 years old, ref No42

properties.Place: Downs, Grows on the lip of the Gorge on the path round Fairyland, can be seen from the path down Bridge Valley Road
properties.Comments: This tree is at least a century old, but, as it grows on the lip of the Gorge on the path round Fairyland it could not be measured. It stands out boldly when seen from the path down Bridge Valley Road, ref No195

properties.Scientific_Name: Quercus cerris x suber = Q. x crenata
properties.Comments: It does come true from seed. Most of the old estates had one, but they have tended to die in recent years. The best survivor has a girth of 480cm, ref No142
Its leaf and fruit are similar to the Hazel bush, but it makes a stout tree with very dark rough bark. A girth of 250cm, ref No171

Named after its Tulip shaped greenish flowers and recognisable by its leaves that appear to have had the tips bitten out of them, a fast growing tree. The oldest is in a grove at Canford Lane with a girth of 470cm, ref No170

properties.Place: Shirehampton, at Crabtree Slip, the little wood off the Portway
properties.Comments: Commonly planted in avenues. There is a magnificent tree with a 480cm girth, ref No64

girth 500cm, age 200. This is the largest of the Horse Chestnut on the Downs. This tree is diseased with bleeding canker, but remains vigorous. A number of other trees have succumbed in the past few years and had to be felled, ref No49

properties.Scientific_Name: Platanus occidentalis x orientalis = P. x hispanica
properties.Sex__Stage: hollow veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: girth 675cm, age 250 years. It fills the valley of the brook, and is hollow. It was in danger of being ruined by fires built inside its hollow trunk, but  recently saved by being bricked up. The species came to Britain in 1690, ref No12

properties.Scientific_Name: Tilia platyphyllos x cordata = T. x europaea
properties.Place: Blaise, in the meadow off Henbury Lane
properties.Comments: A huge rotting stump surrounded by a mass of thin tall trunks, an example of how easily Limes coppice, ref No191

properties.Place: Clifton, garden on St Johns Road
properties.Comments: Widely planted in gardens, in time this becomes a substantial tree and there are a number in the Zoo. A fine one is in Clifton, ref No76
The oldest is a tree in Ashton Park with a girth of 440cm, ref No130

properties.Place: Redland Green, approximate grid reference used
properties.Comments: Girth of 425cm in Redland Green, ref No56

properties.Place: Blaise, at grove in Blaise woods by the bottom lake
properties.Comments: Has recently been cut back to reveal a twin trunk and a single trunk tree, with a grith of 250cm, ref No178

properties.Place: Ashton Park, along the brow of hill
properties.Comments: girth 805cm, age 600years. Largest of a line of six trees along the brow of hill, probably planted at the same time. Hundreds of baby Chestnuts below them, so despite the die back of the main branches, all these trees are still vigorous, ref No2

properties.Place: Blaise Estate, close to the lowest pond on the Trym, Ashton Hill Plantation
properties.Comments: girth 600cm, age 150. Most Wellingtonia in Bristol is roughly the same age,differences in girth reflect their habitat. Some have died or are dying, although they can live for 5000 years. There is a grove of them in Ashton Hill Plantation, ref No14
A young tree, may be this species, ref No79

properties.Place: Clifton, front garden of  a house in Ashgrove Road off Whiteladies Road
properties.Comments: A very fine specimen of this rare tree, with glossy evergreen leaves that flowers in August, in the front garden of  a house. It has twin trunks, ref No86

properties.Place: Richmond Hill at the entrance to a car park
properties.Comments: It will coppice and this can be seen in action on Richmond Hill. The largest is in the Bishops Knoll Wood with a girth of 400cm, but it is 150 years old at most, ref No160

properties.Place: Snuff Mills, hanging over the river Frome, approximate grid reference
properties.Comments: In Snuff Mills Park whose branches are weeping. Its girth is 290cm. There is another Weeping Horse Chestnut in Arnos Vale cemetery, ref No185
It rarely last to a great age, but one has a girth of 250cm.  They turn a fine colour in the autumn, ref No83

properties.Place: Stoke Bishop, a grove on Canford Lane
properties.Comments: This tree suckers vigorously, and can often be seen along Motorways. The undersides of the leaves are white and turn silver in the Autumn. Has a girth of 270cm, ref No157

properties.Place: Henbury, in fields and hedges belonging to the Riding for the Disabled Association
properties.Sex__Stage: hollow, pollarded veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: Ancient pollard oak. A hollow wreck, ivy clad, and collapsing in a hedge. Part of a large group of huge pollard oaks in fields and hedges belonging to the Riding for the Disabled Association, with public access by footpath, ref No34
They turn a fine colour in the autumn. The double form, called plena has late and large double flowers and there are two on Clifton Green, ref No84
Uncommon, and does not grow well. One has a girth of 240cm, ref No90

properties.Place: Stoke Bishop, in the grove in a piece of public parkland off the road called Clifton High Grove
properties.Comments: This tree has very graceful fine needles in bunches of five, and is often planted. The largest has a girth of 395cm, ref No150
An evergreen oak, there is a single very young plant in Victoria Square , Clifton, ref No139
Quite commonly used as a hedging plant, this evergreen shrub, with multiple stems, grows as a tree, ref No109
Girth 520, age 150. This cedar comes from Afghanistan, and is characterised by drooping tips to the shoots, ref No43
This is a natural variant in which the leaf is a single blade rather than leaflets. It was quite widely planted about 30 years ago. Has a girth of 130cm, ref No59

properties.Scientific_Name: Platanus occidentalis x orientalis = P. x hispanica
properties.Place: Eastville Park, close to the southern tip
properties.Comments: girth 520cm, iIt seems unlikely that this tree preceded the creation of the park so that it is only 120 years old, ref No41
The tree beside Kings Weston House has a girth of 430cm. It is most notable for a huge branch coming off the trunk very close to the ground, which all children love to climb, ref No187

properties.Sex__Stage: hollow, pollarded veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: Largest of a line of oak pollards planted as part of the wood-pasture of the old Sneyd Park. 60 years ago they were all still fine tall trees, now reduced to hulks, dominated by young ash trees. Some still vigorous, some have collapsed, ref No10
In Kings Weston there is a grove of them. The largest is in Greville Smythe park, a tree with a girth of 350 that can?t be more than 120 years old, ref No161

properties.Place: Clifton Downs, inside Wills Hall on the edge of the Downs
properties.Comments: Unmeasured, on the edge of the Downs, ref No128

properties.Place: Knoll Hill, Bishops Knoll Wood, Bramble Lane,Stoke Bishop
properties.Comments: Girth 710cm, age 150.  This colossal specimen, still surrounded by its Victorian ironwork, cannot have been planted earlier than 1860. It is one of the parents of Cupressus leylandii, so commonly, and rashly, planted as screening today, ref No3

properties.Place: Downs, part of an avenue near Clay Pit Road
properties.Comments: Like all limes it is slow growing. The largest is on the Downs, with a girth of 480 cm. This would imply an age of over 250 years, ref No118

properties.Place: Clifton, top of Bridge Valley Road
properties.Comments: A twin trunked tree with a total girth at the base of 600cm, each trunk 350cm. It looks as if these are two trees growing from two original conjoined seeds and totally dominates the road, ref No200

properties.Place: Clifton, private garden opposite the Victoria Rooms
properties.Comments: This is a wonderful form and probably the oldest is in the private garden opposite the Victoria Rooms in Clifton. It hangs over the pavement, ref No68

properties.Place: Clifton, Victoria square beside the centre path
properties.Comments: Five of these have recently been established in Victoria Square, Clifton beside the centre path, to replace the original beech trees, ref No137
This is an uncommon Japanese tree, a young tree with a girth of 150cm, ref No111

properties.Place: Clifton Zoo, just by the entrance
properties.Comments: The variegated form in the Zoo just by the entrance is the best example, and the only one in Bristol, ref No89
The finest is the one in the grounds of Clifton College, planted in 1955, with a girth of 260cm. It is on private property but readily seen from public roads, ref No87
Now often planted in gardens, but old specimens are uncommon, ref No106
A native small tree, and a number of varieties and species are often planted in gardens and car parks, but rarely in parks. Present in Canford Cemetery and Cumberland Basin, ref No163
girth 700cm, age 550. This very vigorous stump appears to pre-date the original villa, and has survived the original building of the hospital, and its recent reconstruction, ref No6
This is a large sprawling tree, with dark leaves that turn a wonderful purple in the autumn. It is rare, and the two best are by the Wills Tower and in the Zoo, ref No149

properties.Place: Snuff Mills, immediately above a vertical former quarry cliff on the edge of Snuff Mills park on the very edge of the path
properties.Comments: This tree defies gravity. It is a very ancient, squat tree, ref No193

properties.Place: Snuff mills, on the banks of the Frome in Snuff Mills Park
properties.Comments: Its branches weep down towards the light reflected from the river, ref No192

properties.Scientific_Name: Platanus occidentalis x orientalis = P. x hispanica
properties.Place: Tiny strip of woodland off Kings Weston lane
properties.Comments: Girth 600cm, age 200. There are three giant planes. Until 5 years ago tall trees, fears they might collapse led to all three being cut down to about 20 feet in height, putting out new shoots. Whereas once they dominated, now harder to find, ref No19

properties.Place: Clifton, in the triangle outside the Lord Mayors House near the Proctors Fountain
properties.Comments: It must have been planted c 1950 in the triangle outside the Lord Mayors House near the Proctors Fountain. Its girth is only 130cm, ref No138
A slow growing small tree with amazing autumn colour, that is widely planted in gardens, but rarely in parks. West mall gardens Clifton have some good examples, ref No129

properties.Place: Combe Dingle, Blaise estate close to the stream near the lowest pond
properties.Comments: This is the largest of the three Wellingtonias in the Blaise estate, perhaps because it is growing so close to the stream near the lowest pond. Its girth is 710cm, ref No4
Noted as Chinese Ehretia, a tree believed to be this grows by the children?s playground in Blaise with a girth of 190cm, ref No85
This variety grows in a columnar form, but is not often planted, this tree has a girth of 260cm, ref No140

properties.Place: Blaise, the meadow off the Henbury Road
properties.Comments: girth 700cm age 550 years old. This huge tree is in the meadow off the Henbury Road. It has vast horizontal branches, ref No5

properties.Place: Brandon Hill, it is just inside the park-keepers compound
properties.Comments: Girth 500cm, age 300 years old, has boughs twenty metres long. It is just inside the park-keepers compound, but dominates the area. It is the oldest tree in this park, which has been a public open space for 800 years, ref No50
This grows in a columnar form, but is rather rare in Bristol, ref No66

properties.Place: Eastville Park, on the bank of the Frome
properties.Comments: Distinguished by the pale under-surface of the leaves, this has a variety of attractive forms. An ancient bole on the bank of the Frome in Eastville Park, measures 390cm, ref No176

Sometimes called Ash Leaf Maple as its leaves are quite unlike other maples with attractive flowers in spring, and pretty shoots when young, but it does not age well. Commonly planted, the best is in Canford Cemetery, girth 200cm, ref No123

As an experiment after the disease a species believed to be resistant to Dutch Elm Disease was planted on Clifton Green. Of the five trees planted only one has grown into the canopy, the others all having collapsed in storms, ref No95
This is a native tree, in appearance similar to a Beech, a girth of 325cm, ref No103

properties.Place: Brislington Victory Park, in a hedge on the north east edge of the Park
properties.Comments: 580 cm in girth and perhaps 380 years old. Is in a hedge on the north east edge of the Park, ref No26

properties.Place: Sneyd Park Nature Reserve, in the upper reaches
properties.Comments: This species is distinguished by holding its unopened cones on its branches for years, waiting for a fire to come to open them. There is an unhappy specimen with a girth of 170cm, ref No152

properties.Place: Ashton Park, close to the main drive from Clifton, close to the top of the hill
properties.Comments: The oldest is in Ashton Park, with a girth of 480cm, and an age of 200 or more, ref No145
There are three Cedars all the same size and age, though one unfortunately is dying. There are probably more Lebanon Cedars in Britain than in the state of Lebanon, ref No16
A North American species which looks superficially like an Ash. The fruit are inedible. There are three on the Downs the largest with a girth of 250cm, ref No172

properties.Place: By the Senate House on Woodland road
properties.Comments: There is an avenue of them at Oldbury Court, and at  Eastwood Farm Park. There is a young tree on Woodland road with a girth of just 170cm, but which is nearly 30m high, ref No88

properties.Place: Bath Bridge, sprawls along the bank at the new cut, close by the Bath Bridge roundabout
properties.Comments: ref No189

girth 570cm, age 170 This huge dead stump more recently was trimmed back for safety reasons, but in the last year or so fungus has attacked and killed it, the fungus growth can still be seen as a black network clinging to the wood, ref No28
A very common native tree, and the Irish form whose branches grow vertically is the commonest planted especially in cemeteries. The champion tree is on the Downs with a girth of 480cm, ref No182

properties.Place: Stoke Bishop,Just off Stoke Park Road in the grounds of Trinity College, and opposite the University Botanic Garden
properties.Sex__Stage: hollow, pollarded veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: Girth 675mm, age 700. This fine leaning veteran pollard is  easily seen, ref No11
This has magnificent autumn colouring and leaves rather like a Maple. Rare, but increasingly planted. A girth of 190cm, ref No167
girth 595cm, age 150. One of the few trees from the original planting. Its horizontal branches, twenty metres long, are dramatic, ref No23
This is a rare tree that flowers in September. It is found at just two sites in Bristol in Malago Park and in Kingsdown, ref No113
Hollies are very widespread but mostly form an understory because they are so tolerant of shade. On occasion they can make substantial trees and there is one with a girth of 300cm, ref No100

properties.Place: Shirehampton, Crabtree Slip wood, off the Portway
properties.Comments: The largest with a girth of 240cm, ref No116
This is the commonest Christmas Tree, and there are a number of tall young trees in Combe Dingle, with a girth of around 180cm, ref No136
This is a fast growing North American oak, with splendid colour in some autumns and very large leaves with fine points. The bests is at Blaise, with a girth of 280cm, ref No143
This is the wild cherry of the north of the UK, but rare here as a wild tree, though it grows well. A fine young tree grows in St Andrews churchyard, Clifton with a girth of 90cm, ref No80
Only one mature tree, girth 200cm. Distinguished by flowers in March and early start to red autumn colour in September, ref No133

properties.Place: Knoll Hill, Bishops Knoll Wood, Bramble Lane, Stoke Bishop
properties.Comments: It was widely planted on the Downs in the 1880s. The largest is in the Bishops Knoll Wood with a girth of 460cm. However it is unlikely to be much more than 150 years old, ref No151

properties.Sex__Stage: hollow veteran or very large tree
properties.Comments: It is hollow, has lost its top, and Has a girth of 470cm. There is footpath access. Five others have a girth of 425cm in Redland Green, the Downs, Bedminster Down, and Victory Park, ref No5656

properties.Place: Clifton, outside the Senate House on Woodland Road
properties.Comments: An American tree with leaves a yard long grows on Woodland Road, ref No112
The largest is in Eastville Park with girth of 240cm. Fast growing and almost evergreen, recently planted in parks and as a street tree, prominent on Park Row, ref No53
Girth 530cm, age 120. This one has developed huge buttresses to strengthen it against the wind. Poplars are exceptionally fast growing trees, ref No38
A rare tree looking almost identical to a Sycamore, but with blunter leaves, that flowers at the end of February. A fine one in Clifton has a girth of 280cm, ref No127

This small tree grows on the slope of Brandon Hill, it was planted in 1973 as part of plant a tree year, and already has a girth of 300cm, a growth rate of almost 8 cm a year, three times that of most trees, ref No201
Uncommon, but there are three young trees, ref No55
Two magnificent trees in Castle Park at with the same girth, ref No94
Widely planted in recent years, the largest is in Greville Smythe Park with a girth of 290cm, and the same size on College Green, planted in 1950, ref No132
This is quite often planted, but rarely does well in Bristol, the best is in Eastville Park with a girth of 200cm, ref No153

properties.Scientific_Name: Tilia platyphyllos x cordata = T. x europaea
properties.Comments: girth 500cm, age 300, typically have dense masses of growth around the base of the trunk and in the middle of the tree. The trees in the avenue have suffered different fates down the years, and are very hard to measure accurately, ref No48
In Kings Weston there is a grove of them. The largest is in Greville Smythe park, a tree with a girth of 350 that can?t be more than 120 years old, ref No161
Not often planted, but often self sown by squirrels. The largest has a girth of 370cm, suggesting it is around 160 years old, ref No173

properties.Scientific_Name: Platanus occidentalis x orientalis = P. x hispanica
properties.Place: Tiny strip of woodland off Kings Weston lane
properties.Comments: girth 600cm, age 200. There are three giant planes. Until 5 years ago tall trees, fears they might collapse led to all three being cut down to about 20 feet in height, putting out new shoots. Whereas once they dominated, now harder to find, ref No21

properties.Place: Westbury, Badocks Wood, close to the path up the stream
properties.Comments: This is a remarkable tree, which has five separate trunks, and a total girth of 550cm, ref No184

properties.Place: Henbury, is in an ancient hedge line, and on the footpath through the Golf course
properties.Comments: girth 505cm, age 300. This tree is in an ancient hedge line, and on the footpath through the Golf course, which is otherwise private. It is the largest of several oaks in this hedge, ref No47
girth 520cm, age 150. There are some eight Holm Oaks which were planted in c 1850. This specimen has a wonderfully contorted and twisted bole, as a result of pollarding down the years, ref No45

properties.Place: Shirehampton, lies by the path round the Golf course
properties.Comments: Girth 520cm, age 320, ref No40
ref No92
An interesting variety with leaves that have five long fingers, and holds its foliage later than other planes. A young tree with a girth of about 100cm, ref No158
In Snuff Mills Park whose branches are weeping. Its girth is 290cm. There is another Weeping Horse Chestnut in Arnos Vale cemetery, ref No185
